I had a great time meeting with some of Alaska’s best and brightest across the state—young women and men who have accepted appointments to our nation’s military service academies for the Class of 2025. I nominated 41 Alaskans to the service academies this year and, so far, 16 have been offered full appointments.

In Ketchikan, I met with Laura Sherrill (via Facetime!) and her mom, Colleen. Laura will be attending the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy, following in both her father and brother’s footsteps. Laura is a 2020 graduate of Ketchikan High School.

In Juneau, I met with Avery Kreischer and her parents, Jon and Lindsay. Avery will be attending the U.S. Air Force Academy. Avery is a 2021 graduate of Thunder Mountain High School. Also joining us was my Academy Board chair, Win Gruening.

In Haines, I met with Haley Boron and her parents, Matt and Lillian. Haley will be attending the Air Force Academy. Haley is a 2021 graduate of Haines High School. Also joining us were Haines Mayor Doug Olerud and two of my Academy Board members, Bill Thomas and Mark Smith.

And, lastly, in Anchorage, I met with Trinity Heine along with her parents, Chris and Turquoise, and Kai Miner, along with his mom, Laurelyn. Both Trinity and Kai are 2021 South High graduates. Trinity will be attending the Air Force Academy, and Kai is headed to the U.S. Military Academy.

I’m so proud of these young Alaskans and wish them all the best as they begin this exciting new chapter.

In Alaska, we know firsthand the importance of tourism to our state’s economy. In 2020 alone, the cancellation of the cruise ship season has caused an estimated revenue loss of over $90 million to the State, $98 million to local governments, and over $1 billion in lost revenue for local businesses. My bill which passed the Senate this week, the Alaska Tourism Restoration Act, alleviates the Passenger Vessel Services Act (PVSA) restriction that prevents cruise ships from transporting passengers between Washington State and Alaska. During a Senate Committee on Indian Affairs hearing, I underscored the importance of tourism to the entire Alaskan economy, but also specifically Alaska Native communities. Here’s a round-up of my week, including some of the legislation I’ve been working on, committee activity that I participated in and other events I was part of:

-> Last week I was out on the road traveling to and around Northeast Arkansas. It was great to visit so many communities and have opportunities to discuss what the latest news is, the pressing issues that need attention and ways my office can help. You can check out a recap of my trip here: https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/dr-boozman-s-check-up?id=11BD5221-71DB-46E6-B4D1-9A00B95344DF

-> At a Senate Environment and Public Works Committee hearing on Thursday, I discussed the I-40 bridge with USDOT leadership and the need to cooperate with all local and state entities to help safely reopen it. This is a real-world example of the need for targeted investment in our core infrastructure, including roads and bridges, which Senate Republicans have offered in our latest proposal: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jhANRmffHhM. 5NEWS reported on my efforts to help ensure the process to manage this situation and repair the bridge is collaborative, efficient and ultimately leads to a successful, speedy outcome: https://www.5newsonline.com/article/news/national/arkansas-senator-john-boozman-urges-dot-to-safely-quickly-repair-i-40-bridge/527-9df7ef3a-bbcc-4772-a7d7-184c039fd171

-> Today, I also convened a call with Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg and members of the Arkansas and Tennessee Congressional Delegations to urge him to support the efforts to safely and efficiently repair the I-40 bridge. Sec. Buttigieg assured us the U.S. Department of Transportation is working with both the AR and TN transportation departments to ensure a pathway to efficiently repairing and reopening the bridge and that his staff would continue to communicate with and update us as the process advances: https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?id=4E55AC30-498A-4645-B494-695135DD3B7B

-> This has been National Police Week, so I shared my support for our law enforcement officers in a speech on the Senate floor and thanked them for doing their important job with or without thanks. This week especially has been a time to show them our gratitude not just with words, but action. I'm sponsoring the Back the Blue Act and the Protect and Serve Act to support police and help them keep our communities safe. I also paid tribute to the AR's fallen officers who died in the line of duty this past year: James Dancy (North Little Rock), Travis Wallace (Helena-West Helena), Kevin Collins (Pine Bluff) and Brent Scrimshire (Hot Springs). We're forever grateful for each of them: https://www.boozman.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/press-releases?id=AA01F477-9848-4510-B2BB-C733817E912C

-> We should always be looking for ways to better support military families. I’m proud to have helped lead a bipartisan effort aimed at doing that in two specific ways: meeting employment and childcare needs. My recently introduced Jobs and Childcare for Military Families Act seeks to do both. Yesterday, I chaired my first Transportation and Housing Appropriations Subcommittee hearing, where we talked with a panel — which included Ed Sniffen, Deputy Director at the Hawai‘i Department of Transportation — about how to make sure our infrastructure and transportation systems are resilient against the growing impacts of climate change. Because right now, they're not.

As sea levels rise and extreme weather caused by rising global temperatures becomes more and more common, we need to move past quick fixes and take comprehensive action to help our communities adapt to the impacts of climate change. Every day we waste, we become more vulnerable. In Hawai‘i, we know this all too well.

Resiliency to climate change needs to be a core feature of our infrastructure and transportation — not just an added luxury. We've got work to do, and yesterday's hearing was a great first step. I'm ready to make sure we get the job done.

Our allies and partners in the Indo-Pacific are worried about America’s ability to deter and defeat China’s use of military force. I heard it myself when I visited in 2018.

They were trying to figure out if we would be there for them when that happened…or if they needed to start cozying up to China.

The significant investment in the military we had under President Trump was an encouraging sign to our allies and partners.

But now they see something different — they see President Biden’s defense budget that doesn’t even keep up with inflation, let alone match the real growth we need to implement the National Defense Strategy, which is our blueprint for pushing back on China.

President Biden’s talk about supporting our allies is meaningless without a strong defense budget to back it up. I know it, President Biden knows it, China knows it, and our allies and partners know it too.

Watch or read my full floor speech here: https://www.inhofe.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/inhofe-on-senate-floor-a-strong-military-is-the-foundation-for-americas-alliances-and-partnerships
